sections.title: ETF Portfolio Construction
sections.subtitle: Design a portfolio that matches your goals and risk tolerance

sections.title: üéØ The 3-Fund Portfolio
sections.content: The legendary Bogleheads 3-fund portfolio has beaten 90% of professional investors over 20+ years. It uses just 3 ETFs: US stocks, international stocks, and bonds. Simple, effective, and proven. This lesson shows you how to build it.

sections.title: üìä Asset Allocation: The Most Important Decision
sections.content:
Studies show that asset allocation (how you divide your money between stocks, bonds, and other assets) determines 90% of your portfolio's returns. Stock picking and market timing contribute less than 10%.

Your allocation should match:
‚Ä¢ Your age

‚Ä¢ Risk tolerance

‚Ä¢ Time horizon

‚Ä¢ Financial goals

‚Ä¢ Income needs

üéØ The Age-Based Rule:

Traditional rule: Bonds = Your Age
‚Ä¢ Age 25: 25% bonds, 75% stocks

‚Ä¢ Age 40: 40% bonds, 60% stocks

‚Ä¢ Age 65: 65% bonds, 35% stocks

Modern rule (longer lifespans): Bonds = Your Age - 20
‚Ä¢ Age 25: 5% bonds, 95% stocks

‚Ä¢ Age 40: 20% bonds, 80% stocks

‚Ä¢ Age 65: 45% bonds, 55% stocks

The modern rule accounts for longer retirements and lower bond yields.

üí™ Risk Tolerance Test:

Imagine your $100,000 portfolio drops to $70,000 in a market crash. Would you:

A) Panic and sell everything ‚Üí 30% stocks, 70% bonds
B) Feel anxious but hold ‚Üí 50% stocks, 50% bonds
C) Feel uncomfortable but stay invested ‚Üí 70% stocks, 30% bonds
D) Buy more at lower prices ‚Üí 90% stocks, 10% bonds
E) Not even check your account ‚Üí 100% stocks

Your answer reveals your true risk tolerance. Be honest‚Äîoverestimating leads to panic selling at the worst time.

points.title: Aggressive (Age 20-35, High Risk Tolerance)
points.description: 90% stocks (60% US / 30% International), 10% bonds. Expected return: 9-10% annually. Max drawdown: -50% in crashes. Best for: Young investors with 30+ year horizons who can stomach volatility.

points.title: Moderate (Age 35-55, Medium Risk Tolerance)
points.description: 70% stocks (50% US / 20% International), 30% bonds. Expected return: 7-8% annually. Max drawdown: -35% in crashes. Best for: Mid-career investors balancing growth and stability.

points.title: Conservative (Age 55-70, Low Risk Tolerance)
points.description: 40% stocks (30% US / 10% International), 60% bonds. Expected return: 5-6% annually. Max drawdown: -20% in crashes. Best for: Pre-retirees prioritizing capital preservation.

points.title: Income-Focused (Retirees)
points.description: 30% stocks (20% US / 10% International), 50% bonds, 20% dividend stocks/REITs. Expected return: 4-5% annually plus 3-4% income. Best for: Retirees needing steady income with some growth.

sections.title: üèóÔ∏è The Classic 3-Fund Portfolio
sections.content:
This is the gold standard for passive investors:

üì¶ The Three Funds:

1. US Total Stock Market ETF (VTI or ITOT)
‚Ä¢ Holds 3,500+ US companies

‚Ä¢ Covers entire US economy

‚Ä¢ Core holding for growth

2. International Total Stock Market ETF (VXUS or IXUS)
‚Ä¢ Holds 8,000+ non-US companies

‚Ä¢ Diversifies beyond US

‚Ä¢ Captures global growth

3. US Total Bond Market ETF (BND or AGG)
‚Ä¢ Holds 10,000+ US bonds

‚Ä¢ Provides stability and income

‚Ä¢ Cushions stock market crashes

üéØ Sample Allocations:

Age 25 (Aggressive):
‚Ä¢ 63% VTI (US stocks)

‚Ä¢ 27% VXUS (International stocks)

‚Ä¢ 10% BND (Bonds)

Age 40 (Moderate):
‚Ä¢ 50% VTI

‚Ä¢ 20% VXUS

‚Ä¢ 30% BND

Age 60 (Conservative):
‚Ä¢ 35% VTI

‚Ä¢ 15% VXUS

‚Ä¢ 50% BND

üí∞ Why This Works:

‚Ä¢ Ultra-low costs (0.03-0.07% expense ratios)

‚Ä¢ Maximum diversification (20,000+ securities)

‚Ä¢ Tax-efficient (minimal distributions)

‚Ä¢ Simple to manage (rebalance once per year)

‚Ä¢ Proven track record (beats 90% of active managers)

Warren Buffett, Jack Bogle, and countless financial advisors recommend this approach.

sections.title: üé® Enhanced Portfolios: Adding Flavor
sections.content:
Once you master the 3-fund portfolio, you can add 'satellite' positions for specific goals:

üöÄ Growth-Focused (Add 10-15%):
‚Ä¢ QQQ (Nasdaq 100) - Tech-heavy growth

‚Ä¢ VUG (US growth stocks) - Large-cap growth

‚Ä¢ VB (Small-cap stocks) - Higher growth potential

üí∞ Income-Focused (Add 10-20%):
‚Ä¢ VYM (High dividend yield) - 3%+ dividends

‚Ä¢ VNQ (REITs) - Real estate income

‚Ä¢ SCHD (Dividend growth) - Growing dividends

üåç Geographic Tilts (Add 5-10%):
‚Ä¢ VWO (Emerging markets) - China, India, Brazil

‚Ä¢ EWJ (Japan) - Developed Asia

‚Ä¢ VGK (Europe) - European stocks

üè¢ Sector Tilts (Add 5-10% each):
‚Ä¢ XLK / VGT (Technology)

‚Ä¢ XLV / VHT (Healthcare)

‚Ä¢ XLE / VDE (Energy)

‚ö†Ô∏è Important Rules:

‚Ä¢ Keep core holdings (VTI, VXUS, BND) at 70%+ of portfolio

‚Ä¢ Limit any single satellite position to 10-15%

‚Ä¢ Don't add more than 3-4 satellite positions

‚Ä¢ Rebalance annually to maintain targets

Example Enhanced Portfolio (Age 30):
‚Ä¢ 50% VTI (US total market)

‚Ä¢ 20% VXUS (International)

‚Ä¢ 10% BND (Bonds)

‚Ä¢ 10% QQQ (Tech growth)

‚Ä¢ 5% VNQ (Real estate)

‚Ä¢ 5% VWO (Emerging markets)

This adds growth and income tilts while maintaining a solid core.

sections.title: üîÑ Rebalancing: Maintaining Your Allocation
steps: Set your target allocation (e.g., 60% VTI, 30% VXUS, 10% BND) and write it down.
Check your actual allocation quarterly. Most brokers show this automatically.
If any position drifts 5%+ from target, rebalance. Example: VTI grows to 68% (target 60%), sell 8% and buy underweight positions.
Rebalance by directing new contributions to underweight positions. This avoids selling and triggering taxes.
If you must sell, do it in tax-advantaged accounts (IRA, 401k) to avoid capital gains taxes.
Rebalance at least once per year, even if nothing drifts 5%. Pick a date (January 1st, your birthday) and stick to it.
Don't rebalance more than quarterly. Excessive rebalancing increases costs and taxes without improving returns.

sections.title: üí° Tax-Smart Rebalancing
sections.content: In taxable accounts, rebalance by directing new money to underweight positions rather than selling winners. This avoids capital gains taxes. Only sell in tax-advantaged accounts (IRA, 401k) where taxes don't matter.

sections.title: üí∞ Dollar-Cost Averaging: The Consistency Strategy
sections.content:
Dollar-cost averaging (DCA) means investing a fixed amount regularly, regardless of market conditions.

üéØ How It Works:

Invest $500/month into your ETF portfolio:
‚Ä¢ When prices are high, you buy fewer shares

‚Ä¢ When prices are low, you buy more shares

‚Ä¢ Over time, you average out market volatility

üìä Example:

Month 1: $500 buys 5 shares at $100/share
Month 2: $500 buys 6.25 shares at $80/share (market dip)
Month 3: $500 buys 4.55 shares at $110/share (market recovery)

Total: $1,500 invested, 15.8 shares owned
Average cost: $94.94/share
Current value (at $110): $1,738
Gain: $238 (15.9%)

If you'd waited to 'time the market,' you might have missed the dip or bought at the peak.

‚úÖ Benefits of DCA:

‚Ä¢ Removes emotion from investing

‚Ä¢ Reduces risk of buying at market peaks

‚Ä¢ Builds discipline and consistency

‚Ä¢ Works automatically (set and forget)

‚Ä¢ Proven to beat lump-sum timing attempts

üöÄ How to Implement:

1. Set up automatic investments with your broker
2. Choose your ETFs and allocation
3. Set the amount ($100, $500, $1000/month)
4. Pick a date (1st or 15th of month)
5. Let it run automatically
6. Rebalance once per year

This is the strategy used by 90% of successful long-term investors.

sections.title: ‚ú® Key Takeaway
sections.content: A simple 3-fund portfolio (US stocks, international stocks, bonds) with consistent monthly investments and annual rebalancing beats complex strategies 90% of the time. Focus on low costs, broad diversification, and staying invested through market ups and downs.

sections.title: ‚û°Ô∏è Next Steps
sections.content:
You now know how to build a complete ETF portfolio.

Your homework:

‚úÖ Determine your risk tolerance and target allocation
‚úÖ Choose your core ETFs (VTI, VXUS, BND or equivalents)
‚úÖ Calculate how much to invest in each based on your allocation
‚úÖ Set up automatic monthly investments
‚úÖ Mark your calendar for annual rebalancing
‚úÖ Write down your investment plan and stick to it

In the next lesson, we'll explore sector and thematic ETFs for those who want to add targeted exposure to specific industries or trends. üöÄ
